title: 3 Ways to Make a Basic or Complex Family Tree on Excel

steps.title: Click Insert.
steps.content: Click Insert . This is the tab at the top. You can manually create a family tree by using Excel's built-in Shapes and Lines tools. This allows more freedom when creating your family tree structure. If you have a more typical family tree structure, consider using a template instead.

steps.title: Click Shapes.
steps.content: Click Shapes . You can find this in the Illustrations section. A drop-down menu will open with various shapes you can add to your spreadsheet. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Select a shape.
steps.content: Select a shape. For typical family tree formatting, you can select a rectangle or oval shape. This depends on your own preference.

steps.title: Draw the shape.
steps.content: Draw the shape. Click and drag any spot on your spreadsheet to create the shape. The longer you drag your cursor, the bigger the shape will appear. Release your mouse when you have the shape you want. If you need to resize the shape, click it to make the options appear. Then, click and drag any of the circles inwards or outwards.

steps.title: Enter a name in the shape.
steps.content: Enter a name in the shape. Double-click the shape to open the text field. Type any name(s) into the field. If needed, select the text and use the Font menu to customize the size, font, color, and more.

steps.title: Copy and paste more shapes.
steps.content: Copy and paste more shapes. Right-click the shape and click Copy . Right-click another spot on the spreadsheet, and then click the icon for Paste - Keep Source Formatting . You can also press CTRL + C (Windows) or Command + C (Mac) to copy, and then press CTRL + V (Windows) or Command + V (Mac) to paste. If you need to rearrange or reposition the shape, click and drag it.

steps.title: Add more names.
steps.content: Add more names. Click the shape to add a name. Repeat this for as many shapes as you need.

steps.title: Click Shapes again.
steps.content: Click Shapes again. This is on the Insert tab. A drop-down menu will open.

steps.title: Select a line.
steps.content: Select a line. You can use a simple line or line arrow to connect your shapes together.

steps.title: Draw your lines.
steps.content: Draw your lines. Click and drag an area on your spreadsheet to draw your line. If you misplace the line, click and drag it so it connects your shapes together. You can copy and paste the line you drew, or you can continue drawing new lines by clicking Insert > Shape > Line .

steps.title: Export your family tree (optional).
steps.content: Export your family tree (optional). If you want to print your family tree, you can export your spreadsheet as a PDF. Do the following: Click File . Click Export . Click Create PDF/XPS . Select a file location. Click Publish .

steps.title: Click Insert.
steps.content: Click Insert . This is the tab at the top. [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source SmartArt is available on Excel 2007 and newer.

steps.title: Click SmartArt.
steps.content: Click SmartArt . You can find this in the Illustrations section, underneath 3D Models . A new window will open.

steps.title: Click Hierarchy.
steps.content: Click Hierarchy . This tab is on the left, between Cycle and Relationship .

steps.title: Select a style.
steps.content: Select a style. When you click an option, you'll see a preview on the right. You can edit the colors and format later, if needed. Some styles have the option for photos.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . The blank family tree will be created. If you need to change its size, click it. Drag one of the circles inwards to make it smaller or outwards to make it bigger.

steps.title: Click the arrow to expand the chart menu.
steps.content: Click the arrow to expand the chart menu. This is on the left side of the chart. If you don't see this arrow, click the chart first. A panel will open on the left.

steps.title: Enter your names.
steps.content: Enter your names. When you click a text field, the corresponding square will be selected. The text on the chart will update as you type into the panel. If the style you chose has a picture option, click the picture icon to select a photo.

steps.title: Continue filling out the squares.
steps.content: Continue filling out the squares. Press Enter to create another square for a new generation. If you want to create a square that goes directly under another one, select the first square and press Tab .

steps.title: Edit the squares (optional).
steps.content: Edit the squares (optional). If you need to move a square to change a relation, click and drag it to its proper place. SmartArt should automatically add a line to connect it to its nearest neighbor. If you want to edit how the squares look, click the SmartArt Design tab at the top, or double-click the chart. Select a new style, or click the Format tab to customize it yourself.

steps.title: Export your family tree (optional).
steps.content: Export your family tree (optional). If you want to print or save your family tree, you can export your spreadsheet as a PDF. Do the following: Click File . Click Export . Click Create PDF/XPS . Select a file location. Click Publish .

steps.title: Click File.
steps.content: Click File . This is in the top-left corner.

steps.title: Click New.
steps.content: Click New . You can find this tab in the left panel.

steps.title: Enter "family tree" in the search field and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Enter "family tree" in the search field and press ↵ Enter . You should see a list of results.

steps.title: Click an option.
steps.content: Click an option. This will open the template description and preview.

steps.title: Click Create.
steps.content: Click Create . The template will be downloaded, and a new spreadsheet will open with the new template.

steps.title: Add the names.
steps.content: Add the names. Click a box to open the text field, and then type the names needed. Repeat for all boxes.

steps.title: Export your family tree (optional).
steps.content: Export your family tree (optional). If you want to print or save your family tree, you can export your spreadsheet as a PDF. Do the following: Click File . Click Export . Click Create PDF/XPS . Select a file location. Click Publish .

steps.title: Use colors effectively.
steps.content: Use colors effectively. If you have a lot of names on your family tree, adding colors can help to differentiate and separate generations, gender, paternal and maternal lines, and more. Color schemes can also make your data nicer to look at, especially if sharing with your family.

steps.title: Use a readable font.
steps.content: Use a readable font. Microsoft Excel supports custom fonts . However, certain fonts can be difficult to read especially when next to a lot of other elements. Be sure to use a reader-friendly font style and size.

steps.title: Adjust the print area before exporting.
steps.content: Adjust the print area before exporting. This can save time and effort when you're ready to save. Right-click the chart, and then click Size and Properties . In the left panel, expand the Properties header and make sure Print object is checked.
